title: Angus record breakers bid adieu with Witherswood sale
text:
"They're a nice couple, part of the new farming generation and run a successful operation," he told The Australian Financial Review.

"We loved what we did, but we're both in our 80s and its time to pass on the property to new owners."

The couple, who will retire to Melbourne to spend more time with their family, developed some of the best Angus bloodlines in the country over almost three decades.

They created the "Witherswood Method", based on superior genetics, which has been adopted by many other studs.

Witherswood Angus stud produced some of the best progeny in the country

With no family to carry on the business, they made the difficult decision to offload their herd and properties last year in a three-stage process.

This kicked off when they sold their female herd for more than $2 million in October, a very strong result given the drought conditions.

Advertisement

In March, they sold the stud's remaining 63 bulls including 18 sons of Kingdom K35 and three sired by Klooney, a bull the Woodruffs paid $80,000 far, the fifth-highest price paid for an Australian Angus bull.

Witherswood is renowned among the beef industry

With the Woodruffs selling two smaller adjoining properties to neighbours earlier, total property and stock sales total almost $10 million.

Mr Woodruff described the sale of their stud as "the final peg in the door" with just a clearance sale of farm machinery to come.

Strong outlook

He said the outlook for the beef industry was strong despite the drought conditions, which he said were "part of life".

"When you meet these challenges, they make you stronger."

The sale of Witherswood was handled by Joe McKenzie and Hugh Amery of Landmark Harcourts.

It included a main residence sitting atop a hill, a second residence, selling arena, shedding, stables and yards.

Also included in the offering was a small vineyard planted to shiraz and cabernet.
description: Vendors John and Joan Woodruff made history in 2015 when they were part of a group that paid a record $150,000 for an Australian Angus bull, Kingdom K35.
